children.value: Few applications involve an initial-value problem with just a single dependent variable. Usually there are multiple unknowns and a system of equations to define them.
Variations of the following model are commonly seen in ecology:

children.label: predprey
children.html: dydt=y(1−αy)−yz1+βy,dzdt=−z+yz1+βy, \begin{split} \frac{d y}{d t} &= y(1-\alpha y) - \frac{yz}{1+\beta y}, \\ \frac{d z}{d t} &= -z + \frac{yz}{1+\beta y}, \end{split}dtdy​dtdz​​=y(1−αy)−1+βyyz​,=−z+1+βyyz​,​

children.value: are positive constants. This model is a system of two differential equations for the unknown functions

children.html: y(t)y(t)y(t)

children.value: , which could represent a prey species or susceptible host, and

children.html: z(t)z(t)z(t)

children.value: , which could represent a predator species or infected population.  We refer to this as a
. Both of the equations involve both of the unknowns, with no clear way to separate them.
We can pack the two dependent variables

children.html: yyy
zzz

children.value: into a vector-valued function of time,

children.html: u(t)\mathbf{u}(t)u(t)

u1′(t)=f1(t,u)=u1(1−au1)−u1u21+bu1,u2′(t)=f2(t,u)=−u2+u1u21+bu1,\begin{split} u_1'(t) &= f_1(t,\mathbf{u}) = u_1(1-au_1) - \frac{u_1 u_2}{1+bu_1},\\ u_2'(t) &= f_2(t,\mathbf{u}) = -u_2 + \frac{u_1 u_2}{1+bu_1}, \end{split}u1′​(t)u2′​(t)​=f1​(t,u)=u1​(1−au1​)−1+bu1​u1​u2​​,=f2​(t,u)=−u2​+1+bu1​u1​u2​​,​
u1=yu_1=yu1​=y
u2=zu_2=zu2​=z

children.label: IVPsys
children.html: u′(t)=f(t,u(t)),a≤t≤b,u(a)=u0, \mathbf{u}'(t) = \mathbf{f}\bigl(t,\mathbf{u}(t)\bigr), \qquad a \le t \le b, \qquad \mathbf{u}(a)=\mathbf{u}_0,u′(t)=f(t,u(t)),a≤t≤b,u(a)=u0​,
u(t)\mathbf{u}(t)u(t)
mmm
f(t,u)=A(t)u(t)+g(t)\mathbf{f}(t,\mathbf{u})=\mathbf{A}(t)\mathbf{u}(t)+ \mathbf{g}(t)f(t,u)=A(t)u(t)+g(t)

f\mathbf{f}f

children.value: solver to handle systems is straightforward. Consider Euler’s method, which in system form becomes

children.label: eulersys
children.html: ui+1=ui+h f(ti,ui),i=0,…,n−1. \begin{split} \mathbf{u}_{i+1} &= \mathbf{u}_i + h\,\mathbf{f}(t_i,\mathbf{u}_i), \qquad i=0,\ldots,n-1. \end{split}ui+1​​=ui​+hf(ti​,ui​),i=0,…,n−1.​

children.value: is just Euler’s formula applied simultaneously to each component of the
system. Because operations such as addition and multiplication translate easily from scalars to vectors,
s works for systems as well. Practically speaking, the only changes that must be made are that the initial condition and the
function have to be coded to use vectors.
We encode the predator–prey equations via a function.
, even though in this case there is no explicit dependence on
. The second input is used to pass parameters that don’t change throughout a single instance of the problem.
we must also provide the initial condition, which is a 2-vector here, and the interval for the independent variable.

using OrdinaryDiffEq
u₀ = [1, 0.01]
tspan = (0.0, 60.0)
α, β = 0.1, 0.25
ivp = ODEProblem(predprey, u₀, tspan, [α, β])

. The second input is used to pass parameters that don’t change throughout a single instance of the problem.
we must also provide the initial condition, which is a 2-vector here, and the interval for the independent variable. These are given in the call to

from scipy.integrate import solve_ivp
u0 = array([1, 0.01])
tspan = [0.0, 80.0]
alpha, beta = 0.1, 0.25
sol = solve_ivp(predprey, tspan, u0, dense_output=True)
print(f"solved with {sol.y.shape[1]} time steps")
As in scalar problems, the solution object has fields
that contain the values of the independent and dependent variables, respectively. Each row of
represents one component of the solution at every time step, and each column of
is the entire solution vector at one time step. Since we used
that can be used to evaluate the solution at any time.

t = linspace(0, 80, 1200)
u = vstack([sol.sol(t[i]) for i in range(t.size)]).T    # same shape as sol.y
fig, ax = subplots()
ax.plot(t, u[0, :], label="prey")
ax.plot(t, u[1, :], label="predator")
xlabel("$t$"), ylabel("population")
title(("Predator-prey solution"));

t_E, u_E = FNC.euler(predprey, tspan, u0, 800)
ax.scatter(t_E, u_E[0, :], label="prey (Euler)", s=1)
ax.scatter(t_E, u_E[1, :], label="predator (Euler)", s=2)
ax.legend()
fig
You can see above that the Euler solution is not very accurate. When the solution has two components, it’s common to plot the it in the

From this plot we can see that the solution approaches a periodic one, which in the phase plane is represented by a closed path.

In the rest of this chapter we present methods as though they are for scalar equations, but their application to systems is taken for granted. The generalization of error analysis can be more complicated, but our statements about order of accuracy and other properties are true for systems as well as scalars. The codes are all written to accept systems.
Fortunately, the ability to solve first-order
systems implies the ability to solve systems of higher differential order, too. The reason is that there is a systematic way to turn a higher-order problem into a first-order one of higher dimension.

children.html: y′′+(1+y′)3y=0,y(0)=y0,y′(0)=0. y''+(1+y')^3 y = 0, \qquad y(0)= y_0, \quad y'(0) = 0.y′′+(1+y′)3y=0,y(0)=y0​,y′(0)=0.

children.value: In order to write this problem as a first-order system we define two scalar unknown functions,

children.html: u1=yu_1 = yu1​=y
u2=y′u_2 = y'u2​=y′

children.value: . With these definitions, we have the two differential equations

children.html: u1′=u2,u2′=−(1+u2)3u1,\begin{split} u_1' &= u_2, \\ u_2' &= -(1+u_2)^3 u_1, \end{split}u1′​u2′​​=u2​,=−(1+u2​)3u1​,​

children.value:
which is a first-order system in two dimensions. The initial
condition of the system is

children.html: u1(0)=y0,u2(0)=0. u_1(0) = y_0, \quad u_2(0) = 0.u1​(0)=y0​,u2​(0)=0.

children.value: Two identical pendulums suspended from the same rod and swinging in parallel planes can be modeled as the second-order system

children.html: θ1′′(t)+γθ1′+gLsin⁡θ1+k(θ1−θ2)=0,θ2′′(t)+γθ2′+gLsin⁡θ2+k(θ2−θ1)=0,\begin{split} \theta_1''(t) +\gamma \theta_1' + \frac{g}{L} \sin \theta_1 + k(\theta_1-\theta_2) &= 0,\\ \theta_2''(t) +\gamma \theta_2' + \frac{g}{L} \sin \theta_2 + k(\theta_2-\theta_1) &= 0, \end{split}θ1′′​(t)+γθ1′​+Lg​sinθ1​+k(θ1​−θ2​)θ2′′​(t)+γθ2′​+Lg​sinθ2​+k(θ2​−θ1​)​=0,=0,​
θ1\theta_1θ1​
θ2\theta_2θ2​

children.value: are angles made by the two pendulums,

children.html: LLL

children.value: is the length of each pendulum,

children.html: kkk

children.value: is a parameter describing a torque produced by the rod when it is twisted. We can convert this problem into a first-order system using the substitutions

children.html: u1=θ1,u2=θ2,u3=θ1′,u4=θ2′. u_1 = \theta_1, \quad u_2 = \theta_2, \quad u_3 = \theta_1', \quad u_4 = \theta_2'.u1​=θ1​,u2​=θ2​,u3​=θ1′​,u4​=θ2′​.

children.value: With these definitions the system becomes

children.html: u1′=u3,u2′=u4,u3′=−γu3−gLsin⁡u1+k(u2−u1),u4′=−γu4−gLsin⁡u2+k(u1−u2),\begin{split} u_1' &= u_3, \\ u_2' &= u_4, \\ u_3' &= -\gamma u_3 - \frac{g}{L}\sin u_1 + k(u_2-u_1), \\ u_4' &= -\gamma u_4 - \frac{g}{L}\sin u_2 + k(u_1-u_2), \end{split}u1′​u2′​u3′​u4′​​=u3​,=u4​,=−γu3​−Lg​sinu1​+k(u2​−u1​),=−γu4​−Lg​sinu2​+k(u1​−u2​),​

children.value: which is a first-order system in four dimensions. To complete the description of the problem, you need to specify values for

children.html: θ1(0)\theta_1(0)θ1​(0)
θ1′(0)\theta_1'(0)θ1′​(0)
θ2(0)\theta_2(0)θ2​(0)
θ2′(0)\theta_2'(0)θ2′​(0)

children.value: The trick illustrated in the preceding examples is always available. Suppose

children.html: yyy

children.value: is a scalar dependent variable in the system. You should introduce a component of

children.html: u\mathbf{u}u
yyy
y′y'y′

children.value: , etc., up to but not including the highest derivative appearing anywhere for

children.html: yyy

children.value: . This is done for each scalar variable in the original system. There should be one component of

children.html: u\mathbf{u}u

children.value: for each scalar initial condition given. Many equations for the first-order system then come from the trivial relationships among all the lower derivatives. The remaining equations for the system come from the original, high-order equations. In the end, there must be as many scalar component equations as unknown first-order variables.
Let’s implement the coupled pendulums from
. The pendulums will be pulled in opposite directions and then released together from rest.
function creates an array of the same size and type as a given value, without initializing the contents.

function couple(u, p, t)
    γ, L, k = p
    g = 9.8
    udot = similar(u)
    udot[1:2] .= u[3:4]
    udot[3] = -γ * u[3] - (g / L) * sin(u[1]) + k * (u[2] - u[1])
    udot[4] = -γ * u[4] - (g / L) * sin(u[2]) + k * (u[1] - u[2])
    return udot
end

u₀ = [1.25, -0.5, 0, 0]
tspan = (0.0, 50.0);
First we check the behavior of the system when the pendulums are uncoupled, i.e., when

children.html: k=0k=0k=0

children.value: is used to plot two components as functions of time.

using OrdinaryDiffEq
γ, L, k = 0, 0.5, 0
ivp = ODEProblem(couple, u₀, tspan, [γ, L, k])
sol = solve(ivp, Tsit5())
plot(sol, idxs=[1, 2], 
    label=[L"\theta_1" L"\theta_2"],
    xlims=[20, 50], 
    title="Uncoupled pendulums")

You can see that the pendulums swing independently. Because the model is nonlinear and the initial angles are not small, they have slightly different periods of oscillation, and they go in and out of phase.
With coupling activated, a different behavior is seen.

k = 1
ivp = ODEProblem(couple, u₀, tspan, [γ, L, k])
sol = solve(ivp, Tsit5())
plot(sol, idxs=[1, 2], 
    label=[L"\theta_1" L"\theta_2"],
    xlims=[20, 50], 
    title="Coupled pendulums")
The coupling makes the pendulums swap energy back and forth.
Let’s implement the coupled pendulums from
. The pendulums will be pulled in opposite directions and then released together from rest.
First we check the behavior of the system when the pendulums are uncoupled, i.e., when

children.html: k=0k=0k=0

u2u_2u2​

children.value: You can see that the pendulums swing independently. Because the model is nonlinear and the initial angles are not small, they have slightly different periods of oscillation, and they go in and out of phase.
With coupling activated, a different behavior is seen.
The coupling makes the pendulums swap energy back and forth.
Let’s implement the coupled pendulums from
. The pendulums will be pulled in opposite directions and then released together from rest.

def couple(t, u, params):
    gamma, L, k = params
    g = 9.8
    udot = copy(u)
    udot[:2] = u[2:4]
    udot[2] = -gamma * u[2] - (g / L) * sin(u[0]) + k * (u[1] - u[0])
    udot[3] = -gamma * u[3] - (g / L) * sin(u[1]) + k * (u[0] - u[1])
    return udot

u0 = array([1.25, -0.5, 0, 0])
tspan = [0.0, 50.0]
First we check the behavior of the system when the pendulums are uncoupled, i.e., when

children.html: k=0k=0k=0

children.value: We use a closure here to pass the fixed parameter values into

from scipy.integrate import solve_ivp
gamma, L, k = 0.01, 0.5, 0.0
du_dt = lambda t, u: couple(t, u, (gamma, L, k))
sol = solve_ivp(du_dt, tspan, u0, t_eval=linspace(0, 50, 1000))
plot(sol.t, sol.y[:2, :].T)    # first two components of solution
xlabel("t"), ylabel("angle")
title("Uncoupled pendulums");

You can see that the pendulums swing independently. Because the model is nonlinear and the initial angles are not small, they have slightly different periods of oscillation, and they go in and out of phase.
With coupling activated, a different behavior is seen.

k = 0.75    # changes the value in the du_dt closure
sol = solve_ivp(du_dt, tspan, u0, t_eval=linspace(0, 50, 1000))
plot(sol.t, sol.y[:2, :].T)
xlabel("t"), ylabel("angle")
title("Coupled pendulums");
The coupling makes the pendulums swap energy back and forth.
✍ Rewrite the given higher order problems as first-order systems.

children.value: . (The rest of the population is considered to be recovered and immune.) A typical model is the
